verses.text: Paul, a commissioned envoy of Christ Jesus through the will of God, and Timothy our brother,
to the holy ones in Colossae—the faithful brothers and sisters in Christ: Grace to you and peace from God our Father.
We always give thanks to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ when we pray for you,
because we have heard of your faith in Christ Jesus and the love you have for all the holy ones
because of the hope stored up for you in the heavens. You first heard of this hope in the word of truth—the Gospel—
which has come to you. Just as it is bearing fruit and growing in all the world, so it has been doing among you from the day you heard it and truly came to recognize the grace of God.
You learned this from Epaphras, our beloved fellow-slave, who is a faithful minister of Christ on our behalf;
he is the one who made your love in the Spirit known to us.

For this reason, from the day we heard about it, we also have not ceased praying for you and asking that you may be filled with the precise knowledge of his will in all spiritual wisdom and understanding.
This is so that you may live your lives in a manner worthy of the Lord, seeking to please him in every way: bearing fruit in every good work and growing in the recognition of God.
May you be strengthened with all power, according to the sovereign might of his glory, so that you may have all endurance and patience. With joy
we give thanks to the Father, who has qualified you for a share in the inheritance of the holy ones in the light.
He has rescued us from the dominion of darkness and relocated us into the kingdom of the Son of his love,
in whom we have our release through ransom: the forgiveness of sins.
He is the living image of the invisible God, the preeminent firstborn over all creation.

For in him all things were created—those in the heavens and those on the earth, the visible and the invisible, whether thrones or lordships or rulers or authorities. All things have been created through him and for him.
He himself exists before all things, and in him all things hold together.
He is also the head of the body, the church; he is the beginning, the firstborn from among the dead, so that he might come to hold the first place in everything.
For in him all the Fullness of God was pleased to take up residence,
and through him to reconcile all things to himself—whether things on earth or things in the heavens—by making peace through the blood of his cross.
And you, who were once alienated and hostile in your mind because of your wicked deeds,
he has now reconciled in his body of flesh through death, in order to present you holy, without blemish, and beyond reproach before him—

provided that you continue in the faith, established and firm, not shifting from the hope of the Gospel that you heard. This is the Gospel that has been proclaimed in all creation under heaven, and of which I, Paul, became a servant.
Now I rejoice in my sufferings for your sake, and in my own flesh I am filling up what remains of the tribulations of Christ for the sake of his body, which is the church.
I became its servant according to the divine stewardship given to me for you, to bring the word of God to its full completion—
the divine secret that remained hidden from the ages and from the generations, but has now been revealed to his holy ones.
To them God willed to make known the glorious wealth of this secret among the nations, which is: Christ in you, the hope of glory.
We proclaim him by warning everyone and teaching everyone with all wisdom, so that we may present every person fully mature in Christ.
For this I labor, struggling according to his vital energy that works so powerfully within me.

chapters.notes:
**"Commissioned envoy" (v. 1)**: The Greek *apostolos* refers to a messenger sent with the full authority of the sender. "Apostle" has become a religious title that obscures this functional, legal sense of representation.

**"Holy ones" (v. 2, 4, 12, 26)**: *hagiois* is often translated "saints," but in a first-century context, it refers to those set apart for God's purposes, drawing on the Old Testament concept of Israel as a "holy nation."

**"Precise knowledge" / "Recognition" (v. 9, 10)**: The Greek *epignosis* is an intensified form of *gnosis* (knowledge). It implies a deep, experiential, and accurate recognition of the truth, rather than mere intellectual data.

**"Live your lives" (v. 10)**: *peripatesai* literally means "to walk." In Jewish thought (*halakhah*), "walking" was the standard idiom for one's moral and religious conduct.

**"Relocated" (v. 13)**: *metestesen* was used in the ancient world for the forced deportation or transfer of a whole population from one kingdom to another. It captures the total change of citizenship and jurisdiction Paul is describing.

**"Release through ransom" (v. 14)**: *apolytrosin* refers to the liberation of a slave or captive upon payment of a price. "Redemption" is the traditional term, but "release through ransom" preserves the specific social mechanism involved.

**"Living image" (v. 15)**: *eikon* implies a visible representation that manifests the nature of the original. In the context of the "invisible God," the *eikon* is the means by which the invisible is made visible.

**"Preeminent firstborn" (v. 15)**: *prototokos* can refer to birth order, but its primary Hebrew Bible usage (LXX) relates to status and inheritance rights (e.g., Psalm 89:27). "Preeminent" clarifies that this is about rank and priority over creation, not being the first creature created.

**"Hold together" (v. 17)**: *synesteken* suggests coherence and preservation. Christ is the unifying principle that prevents the cosmos from dissolving into chaos.

**"Fullness" (v. 19)**: *pleroma* was a technical term later used by Gnostics, but here it refers to the totality of the divine nature and powers.

**"Tribulations of Christ" (v. 24)**: *thlipseon* (tribulations/afflictions) refers to the "messianic woes" or the suffering expected before the consummation of the age. Paul does not mean Christ’s atoning work was insufficient, but that the physical suffering of the Messiah’s body (the church) continues until the end.

**"Divine stewardship" (v. 25)**: *oikonomia* refers to the management or administration of a household. Paul sees his ministry as an assigned task within God's household management.

**"Divine secret" (v. 26)**: *mysterion* does not mean a "mystery" in the sense of a puzzle to be solved, but a truth that was previously hidden in God's counsel and has now been disclosed to his people.

**"Fully mature" (v. 28)**: *teleion* is often "perfect," but in the Greek philosophical and religious context, it refers to reaching an intended goal or end-state (*telos*). It denotes wholeness and maturity.

**"Vital energy" (v. 29)**: *energeian* refers to active, effective power at work. "Energy" preserves the sense of an internal, driving force.

verses.text: For I want you to know how great a struggle I am undergoing for you, and for those in Laodicea, and for all who have not seen my face in person.

My goal is that their hearts may be encouraged as they are knit together in love, reaching for all the riches that come from the full assurance of understanding—to truly know the secret of God, which is Christ.
In him are stored away all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
I say this so that no one may delude you with seductive, persuasive arguments.
For even though I am absent in body, I am with you in spirit, rejoicing as I observe your orderly discipline and the solid front of your faith in Christ.
Therefore, just as you received the Christ, Jesus the Lord, continue to live your lives in him—
having been firmly rooted and now being built up in him, being established in the faith just as you were taught, and overflowing with gratitude.
See to it that no one carries you off as spiritual plunder through philosophy and empty deception, which rely on human tradition and the elemental spirits of the world system rather than on Christ.
For in him, the entire fullness of the divine nature lives in a body.
And you have been made full in him, who is the head over every ruler and authority.
In him you were also circumcised with a circumcision performed without hands—by stripping off the corrupt nature of the flesh in the circumcision of Christ.
You were buried with him in baptism, in which you were also raised with him through faith in the effective power of God, who raised him from the dead.
And even though you were dead in your trespasses and the uncircumcision of your flesh, God made you alive together with him, having graciously forgiven us all our trespasses.
He erased the handwritten certificate of debt that stood against us with its legal demands; he has taken it out of the way, nailing it to the cross.
Having stripped the rulers and authorities of their power, he made a public spectacle of them, leading them as captives in his triumphal procession.
Therefore, let no one act as your judge regarding what you eat or drink, or in the matter of a festival, a New Moon, or a Sabbath.
These things are only a shadow of what was to come, but the substance—the body that casts the shadow—belongs to Christ.

Do not let anyone disqualify you from the prize by insisting on self-abasement and the worship of angels, dwelling on visions they have seen, and being puffed up without cause by their own unspiritual minds.
Such a person fails to hold fast to the Head, from whom the whole body—nourished and knit together through its joints and ligaments—grows with a growth that comes from God.
If you died with Christ to the elemental spirits of the world system, why, as if you still belonged to the world, do you submit to its decrees:
“Do not handle, do not taste, do not touch”?
These rules deal with things that perish as they are used; they are based on human commands and teachings.

Although these regulations have a reputation for wisdom because of their self-imposed worship, false humility, and harsh treatment of the body, they are of no value in restraining the indulgence of the flesh.

chapters.notes:
**"Struggle" (v. 1)**: The Greek *agōna* refers to an athletic contest or a strenuous internal battle. Paul uses this to describe his intense apostolic labor and concern for churches he has not personally visited.

**"Secret" (v. 2)**: The Greek *mystērion* refers not to something mysterious or unknowable, but to a divine secret that was once hidden but is now revealed to those within the community.

**"Seductive, persuasive arguments" (v. 4)**: The term *pithanologia* refers to speech that is "persuasive" in a negative sense—smooth talk or rhetoric designed to lead someone astray.

**"Elemental spirits" (v. 8, 20)**: The *stoicheia tou kosmou* can refer to "basic principles" or "elementary teachings," but in the first-century context, it often referred to the spiritual forces or planetary powers believed to govern the physical world and human destiny. Given the context of "rulers and authorities" (v. 15), a spiritual/cosmic nuance is preserved.

**"Fullness of the divine nature" (v. 9)**: *Theotēs* is the state of being God. The translation "divine nature" or "deity" is more precise than "godhead," which has become an archaic theological term.

**"Handwritten certificate of debt" (v. 14)**: The *cheirographon* was a technical term for a signed bond or an acknowledgment of debt. Paul uses this legal metaphor to describe the record of transgressions against God's law.

**"Triumphal procession" (v. 15)**: The verb *thriambeuō* specifically refers to a Roman "Triumph," where a victorious general would parade defeated kings and captives through the streets of Rome to their shame.

**"Substance... belongs to Christ" (v. 17)**: The Greek *sōma* (body) is contrasted with *skia* (shadow). A shadow is cast by a solid object. Paul is saying the Jewish rituals were the shadow, but the "body" casting that shadow—the reality itself—is Christ.

**"Disqualify you" (v. 18)**: *Katabrabeuetō* is an athletic term meaning to "give the prize to someone else" or "umpire against someone." It suggests someone acting as an illegitimate judge of the believers' spiritual standing.

**"Dwelling on visions" (v. 18)**: The Greek *embateuōn* was often used as a technical term in mystery religions for "entering" a temple or "initiating" into a higher spiritual state. Paul uses it here to critique those who claim superior status based on their visionary experiences.

**"Self-imposed worship" (v. 23)**: *Ethelothrēskia* is a compound word likely coined by Paul, meaning "will-worship" or "chosen religion." It refers to a religious practice that originates in human desire rather than divine command.

verses.text: If, then, you were raised with the Christ, seek the things above, where the Christ is, seated at the right hand of God.
Set your mind’s orientation on the things above, not on the things of the earth.
For you died, and your life has been safely hidden with the Christ in God.
When the Christ—who is your life—is revealed, then you also will be revealed with him in glory.

Therefore, put to death the parts of your nature that belong to the earth: sexual immorality, moral impurity, uncontrolled passion, evil desire, and that insatiable greed which is effectively idolatry.
Because of these things, the wrath of God is coming.
You also once walked in these ways when you were living among them.
But now, you must strip off all these things: rage, outbursts of anger, malice, slander, and foul language from your mouth.
Do not lie to one another, since you have stripped off the old humanity with its behaviors
and have put on the new humanity, which is being renewed into a true knowledge that corresponds to the image of its Creator.
In this new state, there is no Greek and Jew, circumcised and uncircumcised, barbarian, Scythian, slave, or free; instead, Christ is everything and in everyone.
Therefore, as God’s chosen ones, set apart and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with a heart of deep compassion, kindness, humility, gentle strength, and a patient disposition.
Bear with one another and graciously forgive each other if anyone has a grievance against another. Just as the Lord graciously forgave you, so you must also do.
And over all these things put on love, which is the unifying bond of maturity.
Let the peace of Christ act as umpire in your hearts, the peace to which you were called in one body. And be thankful.
Let the word of the Christ dwell in you richly as you teach and admonish one another with all wisdom, singing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs with gratitude in your hearts to God.
And whatever you do, in word or in deed, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through him.
Wives, align yourselves with your husbands, as is fitting in the Lord.
Husbands, love your wives and do not be embittered toward them.
Children, obey your parents in everything, for this is well-pleasing in the Lord.
Fathers, do not irritate your children, so they do not lose heart.
Slaves, obey your earthly masters in everything—not with work performed only when watched as those who only seek to please people, but with a sincere heart, out of reverence for the Lord.
Whatever you do, work at it from the soul, as if for the Lord and not for humans,
knowing that from the Lord you will receive the inheritance as your full compensation. You are serving the Lord Christ.
For the one who does wrong will be paid back for the wrong he has done, and there is no partiality.

chapters.notes:
**"The Christ" (v. 1, 3, 4, 11, 15, 16)**: The Greek includes the definite article (*ho Christos*). In this context, it functions less as a proper name and more as a title ("The Messiah"). Retaining the article helps the reader recognize the office and the theological weight of the person.

**"Mind’s orientation" (v. 2)**: The verb *phroneite* goes beyond mere thoughts; it describes an internal disposition, a mindset, or the direction of one's will and affections.

**"Insatiable greed" (v. 5)**: The Greek *pleonexia* literally means "the desire to have more." In a Roman context, this was not just a personal vice but a social disruption. Paul identifies it as idolatry because it replaces God with the pursuit of material gain.

**"Old humanity / New humanity" (v. 9-10)**: The Greek *anthrōpos* is often translated "man" or "self," but it refers to the corporate "old man" (Adam) and the "new man" (Christ). The imagery is of changing clothes—stripping off the identity of the old age and putting on the identity of the new.

**"Scythian" (v. 11)**: To the original readers, Scythians represented the extreme of "barbarian" culture—often viewed as the most unrefined and savage people. Their inclusion here emphasizes that the new humanity transcends even the most extreme cultural and social boundaries.

**"Gentle strength" (v. 12)**: *Prautēs* is often translated "meekness," but it refers to power under control—the quality of one who has the strength to act but chooses gentleness.

**"Act as umpire" (v. 15)**: The verb *brabeuetō* comes from the world of athletics, meaning to act as a referee or judge. The peace of Christ is to be the deciding factor in the community's internal conflicts.

**"Align yourselves" (v. 18)**: The verb *hypotassesthe* is a military term meaning to arrange oneself under a rank. It implies a voluntary recognition of order rather than an ontological inferiority.

**"Work performed only when watched" (v. 22)**: Translating *ophthalmodouliais* (literally "eye-service"). This describes someone who only works hard when the master is looking, performing for the sake of appearances.

**"From the soul" (v. 23)**: The Greek *ek psychēs* (often "heartily") suggests work that engages the entire inner life and vitality of the person.

**"No partiality" (v. 25)**: The Greek *prosōpolēmpsia* literally means "receiving the face." It refers to the practice of showing favor based on someone's appearance, wealth, or status. In God's court, these earthly distinctions carry no weight.

verses.text: Masters, provide your bondservants with what is right and equitable, knowing that you also have a Master in heaven.
Persist steadfastly in prayer, staying alert in it with thanksgiving.
At the same time, pray for us as well, that God may open a door for the message, so that we may speak the sacred secret of the Messiah—for which I am currently in chains—
and that I may make it clear, as I am duty-bound to speak.
Conduct yourselves with wisdom toward those outside the community, making the most of every opportunity.
Let your speech always be gracious, seasoned with salt, so that you know how you ought to answer each individual.
Tychicus, our beloved brother, faithful servant, and fellow-slave in the Lord, will give you a full report of my circumstances.
I have sent him to you for this very purpose: so that you may know how we are and that he may encourage your hearts.
He is coming with Onesimus, our faithful and beloved brother, who is one of your own. They will inform you about everything happening here.
Aristarchus, my fellow-prisoner, sends you his greetings, as does Mark, the cousin of Barnabas (concerning whom you received instructions—if he comes to you, give him a warm welcome).
Jesus, who is called Justus, also sends greetings. These are the only ones of the circumcision who are fellow-workers for the kingdom of God, and they have been a source of relief to me.

Epaphras, who is one of your own and a bondservant of Christ, greets you. He is always wrestling on your behalf in his prayers, so that you may stand mature and fully assured in the whole will of God.
For I can testify on his behalf that he works hard for you and for those in Laodicea and Hierapolis.
Luke, the beloved physician, greets you, as does Demas.
Greet the brothers and sisters in Laodicea, and also Nympha and the church that meets in her house.
When this letter has been read among you, see to it that it is also read in the church of the Laodiceans, and that you likewise read the letter coming from Laodicea.
And tell Archippus: “Pay close attention to the ministry you received in the Lord, so that you may complete it.”
This greeting is in my own hand—Paul’s. Remember my chains. Grace be with you.

chapters.notes:
**"Equitable" (v. 1)**: The Greek *ἰσότης* (*isotēs*) literally means "equality." In the context of a first-century master-slave relationship, this does not imply the immediate dissolution of the social hierarchy, but it demands that masters treat slaves according to a standard of fairness and moral symmetry, recognizing their equal status before their shared "Master in heaven."

**"Sacred secret" (v. 3)**: The Greek *μυστήριον* (*mystērion*) is usually translated as "mystery." However, in the New Testament, it does not mean something "mysterious" or "spooky," but rather a divine plan that was previously hidden but has now been revealed to God’s people. 

**"Messiah" (v. 3)**: The Greek *Χριστοῦ* (*Christou*) is the translation of the Hebrew *Mashiach*. In this context, it functions more as a title ("the Messiah") than a proper name, referring to the promised Davidic king.

**"Making the most of every opportunity" (v. 5)**: The Greek *τὸν καιρὸν ἐξαγοραζόμενοι* literally means "buying back the time" or "redeeming the season." It suggests a wise, strategic use of time, treating every moment of interaction with "outsiders" as a precious commodity.

**"Seasoned with salt" (v. 6)**: In the ancient world, salt was used for preservation and as a metaphor for wit and wisdom. The image suggests speech that is wholesome, stimulating, and "flavorful" rather than bland or corrupted.

**"Fellow-prisoner" (v. 10)**: The term *συναιχμάλωτός* (*synaichmalōtos*) specifically refers to a prisoner of war. Paul uses this vivid imagery to describe those sharing in his suffering for the gospel, framing their imprisonment as part of a spiritual conflict.

**"Relief" (v. 11)**: The Greek *παρηγορία* (*parēgoria*) is a medical term referring to a soothing ointment or a person who provides solace. It suggests more than mere "help"—it implies a cooling comfort in the midst of the heat of affliction.

**"Wrestling" (v. 12)**: The verb *ἀγωνιζόμενος* (*agōnizomenos*) refers to the intense struggle of an athlete in the arena. It indicates that Epaphras’s prayers were not casual but required significant spiritual and emotional exertion.

**"Nympha and the church... in her house" (v. 15)**: There is a minor textual variant here (his house/her house/their house). Following the SBLGNT and the best manuscript evidence, "her" (*αὐτῆς*) is the preferred reading, identifying Nympha as a woman and a significant leader of a house church.

**"Remember my chains" (v. 18)**: This is a poignant concluding request. Paul took the pen from his scribe (v. 18a) to sign the letter personally, likely feeling the weight or the sound of the literal chains on his arm as he wrote.
